issues.text: whether limitation for filing an application to set aside the award began to run against the appellant-defendant number 12 from a date more than a month before November 9, 1948, when a written statement on his behalf was filed stating that the award be declared null and void

anchor.surface_text: The first question to determine is whether limitation for filing an application to set aside the award began to run against the appellant-defendant number 12 from a date more than a month before November 9, 1948, when a written statement on his behalf was filed stating that the award be declared null and void.

anchor.surface_text: The second question is whether the order of the Civil Judge amounted to an order refusing to set aside the award and therefore appealable to the High Court. The High Court hold that it was not such an order and we agree.

holdings.text: The intimation to the pleaders of the parties on February 21, 1948, amounted to service of the notice on the parties about the filing of the award and the objection filed on behalf of the appellant was filed after the expiry of the period of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore agree with the High Court that the intimation to the pleaders of the parties on February 21, 1948, amounted to service of the notice on the parties about the filing of the award and that the objection filed on behalf of the appellant was filed after the expiry of the period of limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14(2) does not require written notice unlike s.14(1); oral intimation to present pleaders suffices as notice to parties per O.III r.5 CPC; limitation under Art.158 runs from service date; even from Sept.7, objection time-barred.

holdings.text: Notice under sub-s.2 of s.14 need not be in writing; oral intimation suffices.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 of that section requires the Court, after the filing of the award, to give notice to the parties of the filing of the award. The difference in the provisions of the two sub-sections with respect to the giving of notice is significant and indicates clearly that the notice which the Court is to give to the parties of the filing of the award need not be a notice in writing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual contrast between s.14(1) (explicitly 'in writing') and s.14(2); notice means intimation per dictionary.

holdings.text: Notice to the pleader is notice to the party per r.5 O.III CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Notice to the pleader is notice to the party, in view of r. 5 of O. III, Civil Procedure Code, which provides that any process served on the pleader of any party shall be presumed to be duly communicated

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of O.III r.5 CPC provision on presumption of communication.

holdings.text: s.42 Arbitration Act does not apply to notices given by courts.

anchor.surface_text: We have been referred to s. 42 of the Arbitration Act for the modes of serving notice. This section does not apply to the giving of notice by Courts. It applies to the service of notice by a party

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.42 textually applies to service by parties/arbitrators, not courts.

anchor.surface_text: and that objections coming under s. 33 of the Arbitration Act also amounted to objections for the setting aside of the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court holding accepted by Supreme Court implicitly in context of limitation and appeal.

holdings.text: The order of the Civil Judge did not amount to an order refusing to set aside the award; appeal incompetent under s.39(1)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: The second question is whether the order of the Civil Judge amounted to an order refusing to set aside the award and therefore appealable to the High Court. The High Court hold that it was not such an order and we agree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No party filed objection praying for setting aside, so no refusal possible; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Jurisdictional objection to award not pressed before trial court, presumed given up; cannot be raised on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was submitted that the objection to the effect that the award was illegal and without jurisdiction, inasmuch as the arbitrator included in the award property which did not fall within the scope of his authority, should have been considered by the trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not pressed before trial court; High Court rightly disallowed on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 of that section requires the Court, after the filing of the award, to give notice to the parties of the filing of the award.
